abstract.text: This article describes the KeyboardKit dictation engine.

inlineContent.text: Dictation can be used to enter text by speaking instead of typing. This can be complicated to set up for a keyboard extension, since a keyboard extensions canâ€™t access the microphone, but KeyboardKit makes it easy.
In KeyboardKit, a
can start dictation from the keyboard extension by opening the main app, perform dictation in the app, then return to the keyboard and apply the dictated text when dictation completes.
ðŸ‘‘
unlocks a
that can be used to perform dictation from the keyboard, as well as dictation-specific views and styles.
KeyboardKit has a
namespace that contains dictation-related types, like
, as well as views that are unlocked by KeyboardKit Pro, like
KeyboardKit has a
that has observable dictation state, as well as auto-persisted, dictation-specific
KeyboardKit automatically creates an instance of this class, injects it into
and updates it whenever dictation is performed.
In KeyboardKit, a
can start autocomplete from a keyboard by opening the main app and let it perform dictation, then return to the keyboard and apply the dictated text.
The open-source project doesnâ€™t include a dictation service. Instead, it injects a
dictation service into
until you register KeyboardKit Pro or inject your own service implementation.
ðŸ‘‘
unlocks a
that can be used to perform dictation from a keyboard extension, by opening the main app and perform dictation there, then (if possible) return to the keyboard to apply the result.
KeyboardKit Pro will automatically register a standard dictation service as the main
when a license is registered.
The
requires that you pass in a
. You can copy the source code for a standard speech recognizer implementation further down, that supports the following locales:

Arabic (ar-SA), Cantonese (yue-CN), Catalan (ca-ES), Chinese (zh-CN), Chinese (zh-HK), Chinese (zh-TW), Croatian (hr-HR), Czech (cs-CZ), Danish (da-DK), Dutch (nl-BE), Dutch (nl-NL), English (en-AE), English (en-AU), English (en-CA), English (en-GB), English (en-ID), English (en-IE), English (en-IN), English (en-NZ), English (en-PH), English (en-SA), English (en-SG), English (en-US), English (en-ZA), Finnish (fi-FI), French (fr-BE), French (fr-CA), French (fr-CH), French (fr-FR), German (de-AT), German (de-CH), German (de-DE), Greek (el-GR), Hebrew (he-IL), Hindi (hi-IN), Hindi (hi-IN-translit), Hindi (hi-Latn), Hungarian (hu-HU), Indonesian (id-ID), Italian (it-CH), Italian (it-IT), Japanese (ja-JP), Korean (ko-KR), Malay (ms-MY), Norwegian BokmÃ¥l (nb-NO), Polish (pl-PL), Portuguese (pt-BR), Portuguese (pt-PT), Romanian (ro-RO), Russian (ru-RU), Shanghainese (wuu-CN), Slovak (sk-SK), Spanish (es-419), Spanish (es-CL), Spanish (es-CO), Spanish (es-ES), Spanish (es-MX), Spanish (es-US), Swedish (sv-SE), Thai (th-TH), Turkish (tr-TR), Ukrainian (uk-UA), Vietnamese (vi-VN)
KeyboardKit Pro adds dictation-related views to the
namespace, to let you quickly add dictation visualization to your app:
KeyboardKit Pro unlocks a
that overlays your app with a dictation view when dictation is active.
This view can be styled with a
, which can be applied with a
modifier.
KeyboardKit Pro unlocks a
that renders a set of animated bars. You can change the number of bars, colors, etc.
This view can be styled with a
, which can be applied with a
modifier.
Dictation works differently in an app, where microphone access is available, and in a keyboard extension, where itâ€™s not. You can use a
to perform dictation from both your keyboard extension and the main app.
To make your keyboard extension start dictation, just call
or trigger a
action. This will open the main app, perform dictation, then (try to) return to the keyboard and apply the result.
Dictation will work automatically if you set up KeyboardKit with a
, as is described in
, and set up the app to handle dictation, as described further down.
Due to Appleâ€™s restrictions on how apps can interact with eachother, KeyboardKit Pro will use
to
try
to identify the keyboard host application, then navigate back to it using a deep link.
If the host application is
not
known or canâ€™t be opened, the user can still tap the top leading back arrow to navigate back to the last app. If the
is nil, your app should point your users to that back arrow.
See the
for more information on which apps that are currently supported, and how to add more apps to this database.
This section describes how to set up an app to start dictation from its keyboard extension and perform the dictation in the main app.

content.text: Step 1 - Set up the required permissions

inlineContent.text: Before you can start dictation, you must add these keys to your appâ€™s
, otherwise the app will crash at runtime:
To share data between your app and keyboard extension, you must setup a shared app group for both targets:
Add this App Group ID to your
â€™s
property, to properly set up dictation for the keyboard and its main app.
To make it possible for the keyboard to open the app and start dictation, you must set up a deep link URL scheme for the app target:
Add this deep link to your
â€™s
property, to properly set up deep linking for the keyboard and its main app.
KeyboardKit uses a
protocol to decouple KeyboardKit from the Speech framework, to avoid having to specify dictation permissions in apps that donâ€™t use dictation.
Hereâ€™s a standard speech recognizer implementation that you can add to your app and inject into the keyboard dictation view modifier:

code: public extension DictationSpeechRecognizer where Self == StandardSpeechRecognizer {
public func requestDictationAuthorization() async throws -> Dictation.AuthorizationStatus {
guard let recognizer else { throw Err.missingSpeechRecognizer }
guard let request else { throw Err.missingSpeechRecognitionRequest }

content.text: Step 5 - Set up dictation in your keyboard extension

inlineContent.text: To set up dictation for your keyboard extension, just set up your keyboard with a
that defines a
deep link, or an
deep link with the standard dictation pattern. See the
article for more information.

content.text: Step 6 - Set up dictation in your main application

inlineContent.text: To even be able to start dictation in the main app from the keyboard, make sure to set up the
deep link in your application.
Next, wrap your app in a
as described in
, then apply the
.keyboardDictation
view modifier to it:

code: overlay: dictationOverlay            // You can use any view

inlineContent.text: The keyboard dictation view modifier has an overlay parameter that defines the view to show while dictation is active. You can use the Pro dictation
with any of the built-in dictation visualizers, or a completely custom view.
You can now start dictation in your keyboard by triggering a
action or by calling
You can override
to customize how the keyboard controller handles the dictation result. If not, the keyboard will automatically send the dictated text to the host application.

abstract.text: KeyboardKit helps you create fully customizable keyboard extensions, using Swift and SwiftUI.
This service can start dictation from a keyboard and
perform it in its main app.
This type can be used to define important properties for
your app, and is also a namespace for app-based features.
This guide describes how to get started with KeyboardKit.
